content.copy: WorkStep is enterprise HR software designed for companies with large warehouse, supply chain, and retail divisions. One component of the software is the surveys being sent out to employees while the other is the reporting that the leaders at the company receive. WorkStep exists to help leaders identify ways they can improve working conditions for employees, thus leading to higher engagement and happiness in the workforce, which in turn leads to reduced turnover, higher productivity, and higher safety.

Since many of these employees aren’t desk workers and often have corporate emails, web-based surveys are sent out to workers’ personal contact info via text and email. Results are anonymous unless workers elect to reveal their contact info on a question-by-question basis, and the aggregated results are summarized and analyzed within the WorkStep app.
As is the case in a typical Series B startup, I wore a lot of hats and had my hands in a lot of areas in the product. I’ll take you through some highlights that I think are interesting.

WorkStep actually started out as a tool for sourcing candidates for frontline jobs, and this was what I was originally brought on to help with (WorkStep HIRE). The software went through a lot of changes during those first several years and not all of the changes were carefully thought through. It was starting to show, and hampering product and engineering’s ability to move quickly, so the product team was approached with the task of “Making the product make sense”. I was the design lead on this project.

Before the company had prioritized this, the other designer and myself had already been sharing ideas with each other. This wireframe was from about 5 months before the project had any kind of traction or direction.

content.caption: An early re-architecture wireframe with some scrapped ideas such as an activity feed, quick links, and a company menu where people could access admin level settings. In my head I was calling it NextStep

content.copy: An emphasis on moving fast caused features and areas to be bolted on without making adjustments to surrounding features that may have been affected, which accumulated several years worth of design and tech debt. But with a definition this broad, there was an added layer of complexity to find out what our internal stakeholders believed this project should solve.
Of course, we also didn’t want this to feel so unfamiliar to people that they felt they needed to learn an entirely new product, or that they’d have a lot of trouble adjusting to the changes we made.

The PM and myself conducted interviews and surveys with both internal stakeholders as well as customers. After creating some opportunity solution trees and better identifying key problem areas, we worked together to highlight both what the “re-architecture” project would encompass along with what it wouldn’t. We didn’t want to change the design so much that what was working was eliminated, but we did want to rename and move things into places that were more self-evident.

Some aspects of this project were glaring issues we all agreed on, while others were things that caused quite a bit of concern with some internal teams, and they needed to be convinced. Data was our friend in these cases, and bringing both quantitative and qualitative data to the conversations made everything go a lot more smoothly.
Instead of trying to do everything, we decided on 4 key areas we thought would give us the best impact for our effort: Reorganization, Renaming, Granular Ability Management, and Clarity of Data.

Clarity of Data was more around clarity around quant data, how it was calculated, and affording better transparency into WorkStep’s algorithms. Reorganization and Renaming were the lenses I was primarily looking at the project through, since this was what I was familiar with and good at. The granularity of the ability management meant that a single customer may want entire pages, sections, or even just functionality on a page turned off for some of their HR team, but turned on for others, so the designs needed to still make as much sense as possible in those cases. One way this manifested was showing tabs on a page even if there were no sibling tabs, because the tab added context to users who may not have access to the sibling functionality and would aid customer support in helping users navigate.

bullets: The team was split on whether we should attempt to do one large release with our new product, or do it in several stages. We ultimately went with stages. Knowing this ahead of time would have changed my approach to some of the work we did.
The Figma library we were building with wasn’t built with performance in mind, and for the larger prototypes it was really showing
There was so much to fix, and so many tangential things that needed attention, it was hard to protect the scope of the project and not commit to fixing other things “while we were in there”

Engineering was simultaneously being tasked with optimizing the app’s performance (new queries to replace a backend architecture that we’d long outgrew) as well as implementing the frontend changes we were proposing. In some cases, performance with old frontend components needed to be prioritized, complicating the rollout.

content.copy: The most multifaceted way we’d painted ourselves into a corner from an IA standpoint was by establishing an architecture around a single type of survey. WorkStep’s primary surveys were based on employee tenure. Other survey types were offered, but they were ancillary. As time went on, we discovered users still wanted these other types of surveys, and to be competitive we needed to offer them. The results data from the various surveys was reported on in largely the same way, so the biggest question was whether users would want to access results in a single area filtered to the data they wanted (e.g. “All Survey Results” but filtered to a specific survey or set of surveys), or specific areas for each survey to see those results (e.g. “Exit Surveys” with a results area.) We wound up going with a blended approach. Actual quantitative survey results resided within that survey’s area while the open text comments were in their own area, aggregated but able to be filtered.

content.caption: The results from an individual user's card sort excercise.
A dendrogram showing how users on average organized WorkStep.

content.copy: There were other “smaller” things we needed to solve, but they had easier solutions. For example, products no longer being marketed were still in the main navigation. We were calling surveys “check-ins” which led to confusion to users and eye rolls from teammates of mine making dad jokes about “kentucky fried check-ins”, “check-in tenders”, and “check-in fried steak”. Also some of the most frequently visited pages were buried 2 or 3 clicks deep.

content.caption: A map of what moved where in the re-architecture project

content.copy: After a year of hard work and planning on everyone’s behalf, WorkStep made more sense. Customer service calls were down, sales were up, customers were vocal about how they liked the new organization, and the customer experience team had fewer requests from their customers to change things.

I have a new appreciation for performant design system components, and in fact this project caused me to revamp the entire design system from scratch. New components had only 12% of the layers, but looked the same. Doing this earlier in the process would have alleviated a lot of sluggishness for designers and prototype viewers alike.

My mind was very much in a “launch, learn, and iterate” mindset for a large part of re-architecture. While I was thinking about it from an architecture standpoint, what it really needed was a full-on content audit. We got to this point on a lot of the content within the areas of the product, but there were others I thought we could fix later once we had more information.

Knowing what I know now, I’d spend a different level of rigor and sweat a lot more of the smaller details, because there wouldn’t be resources to return to the decisions we’d made, and I underestimated the added cost of arming producing marketing with go-to-market and training materials, especially when the project was separated into multiple phases. All said and done, we left the camp grounds cleaner than we found them so I think it was a win.

This one-to-many anonymous messaging feature I designed for WorkStep is one of those projects that seems simple on paper but gets thorny when you start digging into the details. Our customers needed a way to quickly communicate with segments of their workforce during critical situations – think warehouses that need to alert specific shifts about dangerous weather, or distribution centers needing to notify specific departments about operational changes.

The basic three-pane layout was based on an existing pattern in WorkStep designed by Jason Metzgar for the Comments area. A lot about this was really well designed and thought out, and it made a lot of sense to repurpose what we could. The biggest changes were to the message composer.

What made Inform an interesting problem to solve was the balance between giving employers powerful communication tools while preserving employee privacy and preventing misuse. We didn't want supervisors manually selecting individual employees (which would be tedious and error-prone anyway), but the system still needed to be precise enough to reach only the relevant workers.

After looking at what a lot of other folks had done for similar segment / filter / query builders, I picked my favorite aspects and created a segmentation approach that allowed employers to define their audience through attributes like location, department, or shift without ever seeing individual names or contact information. The UI had to communicate clearly who would receive the message without revealing specific recipients, which required some creative approaches to visualization and confirmation screens.

Some users would receive messages in their email, others would receive hyperlinks in SMSs which would direct them to a webpage. The key difference we had to account for was showing the subject line on web browsers.

It was important to show some stats on how many employees received the messages. These were a few different data visualization concepts I put together. We wound up consolidating email and phone into a single channel which allowed us to simplify by quite a lot.

Inform was a sleeper hit. Originally created to be an upsell, not many people were biting, so we wound up including it as part of the overall WorkStep package, and it has since seen a much larger adoption with a lot of people using it for a variety of purposes. We've heard stories of warehouse managers sending critical updates about facility closures during winter storms, and HR teams using it to provide guidance during unexpected operational changes. It's the kind of invisible utility that quietly does its job – which in product design, is often the highest praise.

When we started the Reports project, WorkStep had a section called “Insights” which contained various charts on quant data that was gleaned from the Surveys. As the product gained larger companies, the use cases for seeing different kinds of quant data expanded, and it was difficult to accommodate these in a one-size-fits-all design. My private goal with Reports was to pave the way for eliminating the Insights section altogether (which we eventually did) but more immediately we were putting the user in control of how they viewed their company’s data.

content.caption: Early sketch of what I had in mind for the Reports feature

content.copy: At the start, I saw this as an opportunity to make a fun, visual, drag-and-drop report builder but the PMs (rightly) wanted to ensure we didn’t unnecessarily blow up the scope. It wound up being a series of forms for users to choose their data point, and outside of ordering the cards, offered very little in the way of visual customization.
The charts we were using weren’t very well documented in a single area, so the first thing I did was quickly arrange them into a single spot where we could talk about them.

The Reports feature was being designed for higher-level managers of managers, but also the people who reported to those managers. Through our discovery process we learned the primary use case was exporting to PowerPoint. Most companies had internal templates they used, so we didn’t feel the need to go too far with slide customization, but we did want to give them as much context as possible for what we were providing them.

Translating interactive graphs to a static slide was challenging in that a lot of the minutiae was in tooltips, menus, and callouts, so we worked to figure out a format that could accommodate all the different charts WorkStep offered.

This started from a pretty straightforward observation: employees weren't giving us useful qualitative feedback on WorkStep’s surveys. When someone rated the relationship with their manager a 1 or 2 out of 5, we'd show them an open text field asking for more details, but we'd typically get frustratingly brief responses like “bad boss” or “doesn't listen” Not exactly the actionable insights a human resources person is looking for.

We weren't dealing with lazy respondents – these were people who cared enough to give a negative rating and type something, but they weren't sure what specific feedback would be helpful or how to articulate it. The responsibility was on us to guide them better.

Our solution leveraged LLMs to analyze these sparse initial responses and generate a more specific follow-up question tailored to what the employee had shared. So instead of leaving it at “bad boss,” we might ask, “You mentioned your boss is bad. Is it related to communication style, availability, or something else?” This gave the employee a more concrete direction while still leaving room for their unique perspective.

One big challenge with this was prompt engineering and ensuring the LLM didn’t make tone deaf faux pas, such as asking “Why were you fired?” or “What was it about the sexual harassment that made you uncomfortable?” I can’t take credit here, this was a collaboration between our terrific PM, engineers, and data scientists.

The design challenge that was on my shoulders was making this feel conversational. We needed to strike the right visual tone – curious and helpful rather than intrusive or judgmental. We wanted the follow-up prompt to naturally and not feel like the system was challenging their initial answer.
Some companies were reluctant to enable this since we couldn’t guarantee exactly what would be shown to their employees.

What surprised me was how significantly this improved the quality of feedback. Responses went from 3-5 words to multiple sentences with specific examples. Employers started getting feedback they could actually use to make targeted improvements, and employees felt more heard because they were able to express their concerns more precisely. It was a win-win that showed how thoughtful application of AI can enhance human communication rather than replace it.

A.I. Reply Coaching at WorkStep was one of those features that walked the line between powerful innovation and ethical automation. There were a few core problems at play. For starters, HR teams and managers were overwhelmed by the volume of employee feedback they needed to respond to, leading to delays or templated replies that made employees feel ignored. But for some there was also “blank page syndrome”. However we didn't want to just automate responses entirely – that would defeat the purpose of building human connections.

What I designed was a system that analyzed an employee's feedback, then generated a contextually relevant reply draft. The goal wasn't to remove humans from the loop, but to give them a smart starting point they could edit and personalize.
The trickiest part of the design process was figuring out how to present these suggestions without making employers overly reliant on them.

Early designs had checklists in them that diagnosed a reply, but after our PM read hundreds of replies, she determined there’s really no one-size-fits-all checklist for all replies, and even if there weren’t, we weren’t sure users would want to be reprimanded for not meeting certain criteria. We explored possibilities that tried to help users write in different tones, but ultimately WorkStep is in the business of HR software, we’re not trying to replace Grammarly. Eventually we realized that at least for the first version of this feature, addressing that blank page syndrome would solve the majority of people’s difficulties.
The final design showed the AI-generated draft, but emphasized that it was still the HR team’s message and could be edited.

The feature ended up saving HR teams significant time while actually improving response quality. What was most satisfying was seeing how it helped less experienced managers learn better communication patterns over time – they'd start by heavily editing the AI drafts, but eventually internalized those patterns in their own communication. It became less of a crutch and more of a coach, which was exactly what we'd hoped for.

Commercial real estate is an industry slow to adopt new ways of doing things. Brokers who are doing well for themselves have little incentive to change things, large firms even less so, and tenants are at the mercy of these gatekeepers’ well-established processes. Landlords seem to be involved the least of anyone.

Unilease was created by a commercial real estate broker to streamline the way he did business, making it easier for both brokers and tenants. Part SaaS, part social network, I was brought in to help establish a design system, improve the existing user experience, and expand the toolset Unilease offered with the intent of it becoming a product available to all brokers and brokerages.

A few things drew me to Unilease. First, my good friend and teammate from long ago worked there so I thought it would be great to work together. Second, I really liked founder and CEO Rob Marshall. But above all, the prospect of bridging the gap between two different types of users. I envisioned an experience that could be similar to gig economy products where the tech was ultimately a go-between for people looking for and offering services. Things didn’t quite pan out the way I hoped, but I learned a ton.

The initial brand direction and logo were approached with several goals in mind: differentiate from competitors in the CRE tech space; elevate the company to a more exclusive and luxurious level, but also avoid feeling too affectatious to brokers’ clients. Above all else we were going for trustworthy, clean, energetic, and memorable.

We settled on a simple mark without any visual reference to buildings, offices, or stores since commercial real estate can manifest in a variety of ways. This also harkened back to Unilease’s old logo and felt like an improvement.

In parallel to logo work I’d been picking at a few different style tiles to try to build a common visual vocabulary between everyone and suss out what made the most sense. This whole time I had been working on website concepts that incorporated the new branding. Once we’d settled on a direction, the look and feel of the site began to fall into place.

Ironically right when we were close to deciding on a finalized brand direction, we realized a very similar product in the same space was using close to the same colors and typefaces. We decided to pivot a little. This was a foundation we were all comfortable starting from, and overall I’m happy with how it shook out.

Unilease's biggest opportunity and most interesting challenge was modernizing old ways of doing things. One of these processes, surveying the market, had brokers creating files to describe leasable space their client was looking for, then playing a game of Go Fish with their network via phone and email. Some of the more complex work I did for Unilease involved this process.

If you’re unfamiliar with commercial real state, it’s easy to think of it from a residential point of view. Why not just make a search engine that lists available properties? Landlords could list their properties, tenants could find them, we eliminate the need for brokers, and that’s it. But for a variety of reasons, it couldn’t be this straightforward. For starters, landlords didn’t have any incentive to change the way they did business, and brokers didn’t want to make themselves obsolete. Brokers relied heavily on their personal and professional connections, and a large part of their job was being the purveyors of this closely guarded information of which sometimes they only gained street cred and favors for. Lastly there’s a fairly large company that has an iron grip on commercial properties being listed online, and by becoming too much like it we risked alienating brokers and getting ourselves into major legal trouble.
All that to say, there are much better user experiences to solve this process, but the business strategy and circumstances of the space prevented them from being feasible.

This was simple enough, it’s effectively an “advanced search” the broker sends out to their network to find available properties that might match what their client is wanting. If there were already properties that met those criteria which people in their network had listed within Unilease, we’d let those people know and tell them to , otherwise we’d just let them know their colleague was on the lookout for something matching that set of criteria. The most novel feature we had was the ability to draw boundaries on an interactive map.
The old method of doing this took 7–9 minutes. After my updates it took 1 minute, 16 seconds so 750% faster. So I’d say that’s a win.

This was a classic set of several data entry challenges. Too many fields, all uncategorized, no universal standardization for the data, lack of quality control, and don’t get me started on the stuff that got uploaded for location photography. OCR wasn’t an option, LLMs hadn’t made their major debut, and our dev team was a single guy so it fell on me to design the best data entry experience I possibly could.

Given the criteria the broker entered, we could generate analytics based on peer properties and lease data, which we decided could be a great upsell. Sharing presented an avalanche of complexity. Say a broker was putting together a market survey and they were a member of a team - a hierarchy comes into play where that person’s manager should be able to see the survey as well. Then when the survey is shared with people on the tenant side, depending on how large of an organization the tenant is and how many people are involved in the decision process, the sharing of this private information quickly becomes less and less private. Our dev wanted to run the entire process using RBAC, but pigeonholing users into roles and asking admin users to categorize their team felt like a non-starter.

The big elephant in the room with all three of these tasks was recruiting for research proved really difficult. We had Fullstory and the broker founding Unilease got some of his colleagues to sign up, but I really wanted to have conversations with them and get the details from them. The majority of the user feedback we got was from our founder, Rob. We all wondered if perhaps more junior brokers just starting out might find the software more helpful.

content.h3: Business Strategy for Different Customer Tiers

content.copy: Creating pricing tiers for Unilease was one of those seemingly simple decisions that turned out to be anything but. We were debating whether to add a "Team" tier in addition to the "Free" and "Pro" tiers, and opinions were split on how to approach it. I decided to visualize the problem to help everyone see the implications more clearly. The flowchart mapped out how each approach would affect the user journey, show all the touchpoints where human intervention would be required, and highlighted what technical changes we'd need to make to the app to support each scenario. Although I can’t remember exactly which direction we went, I can safely say the team arrived at a decision much faster.

There’s a lot more that went on at Unilease than can fit in a single case study. I worked on a design system and the flowchart for an entire app. We pivoted strategy a few different times, rebuilt the app from scratch, switched platforms the marketing site was built on, hired freelance help, and shifted the roadmap a lot. I had a good time working with those guys and hope we’re able to do it again sometime.

To be completely candid, I had more than a little reluctance to work on any kind of fossil fuel client, especially Halliburton. But when our director of product design approached me about it, I gave it some thought, researched the industry more, learned about Halliburton’s role in it, and after learning about their sustainability efforts and considered the end users who the project would be helping (basically geologists and scientists), I decided to accept the project.
There were really good people I got to work with at Halliburton, and I was quite happy with how far we were able to push the design for a somewhat conventional company.

Halliburton’s old site felt extremely dated, and their limited color palette wasn’t doing them any favors. Though it was being designed for the web, we knew whatever we’d be creating may be leveraged by Halliburton for other marketing materials. After extensive research and interviews (shout out to our rockstar content strategist Matt Herron), the team created mood boards to share some ideas with the client. There were a lot of rounds, some of which we presented directly to the C suite.

After conducting several workshops with the client, we established a set of modular components that Halliburton was able to use, as well as extensive guidelines on usage. It was my first time documenting components to this level of detail, and I learned a lot on the project.

Wayfinding was a big issue for Halliburton’s audience. We also learned through research that a lot of newcomers to the industry aren’t familiar with the jargon, and visit sites like Halliburton to learn it. This Wizard was designed to help visitors find what they were looking for when they didn’t necessarily know what to call it. Some participants in workshops questioned the need to have another means of navigation on top of search and standard navigation links, but we explained it was like going to the wine shop knowing what you were making for dinner but not knowing what paired with it.

There were several major challenges to the Wizard. The first was that it needed to be able to scale and change with the company, but we didn’t have time to enable management of it (in the traditional sense) within the CMS our engineers were building. The other was that we had no idea how many directions it needed to accommodate, or what the scope of the questions might be. The system we wound up creating used elaborate processes and rigorous guidelines to allow an unusual but effective way of editing the Wizard to keep it from breaking.

Outside of planning and running workshops to resolve all of our Wizard questions, I also designed the interactions and animations. I helped communicate all of this using InVision studio, and fortunately had wonderful dev help from extremely talented developers who could take the ball and run with it.

My final work with Halliburton was on their company Intranet, which took a lot of cues from the marketing site’s design, but importantly differentiated itself so folks weren’t confused as to whether they were looking at public or private content. There were several new components created which were designed to service the internal Halliburton employee rather than external customers.

People close to me can tell you that I can be kind of a schmaltzy guy, and part of the reason I went to an agency was so I could work on bigger name projects. So when I was interviewing with T3 and learned my first client would be Hallmark, you could imagine my excitement! On my second day of work, I flew to their corporate HQ in Kansas City to meet the team and participate in workshops where I learned about the projects and who we were building them for.

We were designing what would eventually become the new Hallmark Cards site. Our engagement lasted over a year, so I was involved in a variety of initiatives: coordinating with other designers on laying the groundwork for a new design system; designing the main navigation; collaborating with Hallmark’s internal stakeholders on how the new site’s registration would work with Hallmark’s Crown Rewards program; and designing the product details page (PDP) to name the big ones.

This was my first time designing a PDP for a company as big as Hallmark, and I learned a lot about order fulfillment and the different ways a product needed to be represented. Designing the find-a-store feature was also a cool challenge with a lot of edge cases to account for.

Flowchart detailing sign up behavior. Hallmark’s leadership wanted user registration to automatically assign a rewards account to any new user signing up. But because customers could enroll in the rewards program at a physical Hallmark store without providing an email address, we wanted to afford the ability to link an existing rewards program account during account registration. Similar functionality existed in the account area, but we knew resolving it here would reduce support call volume to Hallmark.
One of the coolest features I helped with was a means for folks to create custom cards. This was a brand new feature for Hallmark, so our team was able to really have fun with it.

Hallmark saw an enormous increase in card sales after the launch of this new site. Although it was during the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic and folks wanting to reach out to each other from afar was no doubt partly responsible, I know our work contributed to this and at the end of the day helped brighten some people’s days. What more can you ask for? I’ve stayed in touch with some of the people from this era and hope I get to work with them again sometime.

EverlyWell sells at-home lab testing kits for things such as thyroid, vitamins, STD, and food sensitivities. After a user collects their sample (the method which varies from test to test)  and mails it in, EverlyWell’s lab partners process the sample and help the end user make sense of the results.

When I joined, EverlyWell had just raised its series A and had a staff of about 25 people. I stayed 18 months, and during that time it raised its series B, launched two major versions of its results platform, tripled in staff, and began offering several additional tests.

content.h2: Results Platform Redesign, Content, & Design System

content.copy: When I joined, EverlyWell’s results platform had a “one-size-fits-all” approach to 30 different tests, and we consistently heard that users’ results didn’t feel very personalized or actionable. Using low fidelity wireframes, I created a modular content system to outline the different blocks of content we’d show, and when. For example, if a user had taken the same test six times and their latest results were normal, we wouldn’t show the same content as a brand new user who had abnormal results. This was a page from a document intended to get buy-in from stakeholders on what these blocks were, what order we’d show them, and in what phase we’d roll them out.

We were also working to make the experience feel more dynamic and engaging, but we had to strike the right balance with this because some folks may have been getting bad news. Anyone who had biomarkers in dangerous zones would have received a phone call from one of EverlyWell’s medical staff, but still, an overly cheerful animation doesn’t land well with a positive STD result.
A proper design system hadn’t really been established, so we created one in parallel of designing the UX and UI for the new results platform.

EverlyWell had a lot of fragmentation when it came to color. There were two or three blues used for button colors, and three or four different greens used throughout the site. To make matters worse, one of our frontend engineers was colorblind, and it was really difficult for him to notice the differences. Additionally the entire company was wanting to become more ADA compliant, and we really didn’t have any internal guidelines on how that would translate to our work. I followed Lyft’s lead and used their color tool to create a systematic color scheme. Black text was compliant on the 6 inner rings, and white text was compliant on the 6 outer rings. We didn’t use more than a handful of the colors, but it gave us room to grow if we needed. It was much easier to tell the devs to use “Blue 4” instead of “The same one we use for button colors”. Plus since all the colors were variables in the code, it paved the way to more smoothly roll out future branding.

There were a lot of variations on how we’d show the biomarker cards. Some were simple “You have this or don’t” cards while others showed several ranges a person’s results might fall under, each with a lab-provided label we legally had to use. So part of the job was making sure these were all intuitive, looked like they came from the same place, and were flexible enough to include all the content they might contain.

There was a running joke that time spent at EverlyWell was like dog years, because everyone did a lot in a small amount of time. EverlyWell’s branding was purchased through Fiverr, and the marketing site when I arrived had been designed by Funsize. A lot of talented people helped create the 2019 design for the results platform, including Anna Ho, Will Fikes, and Eric Boggs.

EverlyWell’s first big partnership was with health insurance and wellness giant Humana to provide HbA1c and Colorectal Cancer screening tests to eligible seniors through their Humana healthcare plans. Since EverlyWell’s platform didn’t follow any kind of accessibility guidelines, and Humana wanted a co-branded experience, we opted to do a separate microsite to handle the entire process. The results were still shown on the primary EverlyWell platform, and we updated it to allow for co-branding which we knew we wanted to enable in the future and wasn’t a very big lift.
One interesting thing about the flows was that a caregiver could be going through them on behalf of the Humana member, and different verification needed to happen if that were the case.

The Humana collaboration was a huge success. I don’t have numbers on how many tests were registered or how Humana benefited, but this was the first in EverlyWell’s step toward working with enterprise customers and larger providers. It also paved the way for further whitelabeling of the product pages, and increased the team’s understanding of what it took to make a site with AAA WCAG compliance in mind.

When the 2019 Theranos documentary was about to be released on HBO, EverlyWell’s leaders were working hard to close series B funding. The website had only cursory information about the science behind EverlyWell’s tests, and it wasn’t easy to find. With a turnaround of only a few weeks, we planned, designed, wrangled content for, and published a brand new science section prominently featured in the main navigation.

Taking on EverlyWell's product detail page redesign was an interesting challenge – their existing PDPs were functional, but still included the “As seen on Shark Tank!” verbiage and contained 6 tabs of heavy text details describing the tests and what they measured. The team initially approached me to "refresh" the page, but after digging into their analytics and customer feedback, it became clear we needed to do more than just give it a new coat of paint. There was a disconnect between the friendly, approachable brand EverlyWell had built and the somewhat sterile experience of actually shopping for their products.

I worked closely with the marketing team to understand what messaging resonated most with customers, and with the product team to identify where people were getting stuck in the purchase flow. We did some “guerilla user testing” by just asking strangers to look at the site on an iPad, just to get some anecdotal qualitative data on it. The biggest challenge was ensuring it felt medically credible while still having an element of novelty to it, because the majority of the traffic that would be driven to these pages was from Facebook and Instagram.

The redesigned PDP brought their brand personality forward while strategically organizing information to address common questions and concerns at each stage of the decision process. We gave more prominence to their scientific validation, simplified the explanation of how the tests work, and made the benefits more tangible through improved visualization. When we launched the new design, we saw an immediate uptick in conversion rates, which validated our approach and gave us good footing to expand the redesign to other parts of their site.

Insitome (pronounced “insight-oam”) was a company partnered with DNA testing platform, Helix. Similar to 23andMe, Helix sequenced people’s DNA via mail-in saliva samples, but what made them different was providing the data to third-party app developers in a “marketplace”. The idea was for Helix to create a sort-of app store where people making the apps could leverage the DNA you had on file with Helix.
Insitome was one of these creators, and sold separate edutainment modules that used DNA to shed light on people’s various traits.
With branding and packaging created by Elbow, and one product (Neanderthal) already in the wild, my job was to help launch two sister products, Metabolism and Regional Ancestry.

But before we’d do that, there were some problems with the existing onboarding process the team wanted help with. The existing onboarding had several steps, many of which weren’t skippable. Helix acting as a middleman between the apps on its marketplace and the end-user created a lot of interesting challenges from an onboarding perspective. So I put together a bevy of recommended hotfixes to make it easier for folks to activate their accounts and sign in.

There was a contractual obligation with Helix that created an added challenge: both an iOS version and a responsive web version needed to be created in parallel. Since I‘d never worked alongside an iOS developer before, I was grateful to have someone who helped me understand the nuances of layout in iOS and how they differed from web. The good news was the functionality was quite straightforward which made parity fairly easy.

content.copy: Maps were a big part of Insitome. Sitting alongside the director of science content, I acted as a pair of hands to get the regions and migration paths in the right places with the right amount of overlap. I had concepts of maps animating as the user navigated, but the scope was too big for our release timeline.

All three Insitome products were fairly static. The interactivity was navigating from one page to another, so the value I was able to add was helping the team understand the content hierarchy, envision how things would look, and providing as many supporting graphics as I was able.

After launching the Metabolism and Regional Ancestry products, I helped create an ad for Genome magazine. Several rough concept sketches were presented, and the CEO fell in love with the idea of a decoder ring because he thought it would strike a nostalgia chord with the magazine’s audience. I styled and directed the shot, retouched the photos, layed out the ad, and coordinated with Helix’s legal team and Genome magazine.

Toward the end of my tenure after the modules had been released, we wanted to add sharing features in. I created two basic user flows, one for sharing a static image and another for sharing a public user profile.

After the holidays were over, I helped design a new marketing site but before construction was complete, Insitome parted ways with its product and engineering staff to put the company in maintenance mode. Helix shifted its focus to partnerships with healthcare systems and population genomics programs, and discontinued its consumer marketplace.

Each year, Music / Film / Interactive festival SXSW (South by Southwest) likes to highlight some of the lesser-known artists who will be performing. So they invite bloggers and music journalists from around the world to pick any artist on the upcoming SXSW schedule, and write a paragraph about them. 2017 was the first year they moved the guide to the web, and my role as the lead UX designer involved project scoping, persona creation, leading internal workshops, and acting as a liaison between UI, UX, and dev.

The personas we created were provisional in nature. While we didn’t identify festival goers and interview them, we had a lot of friends who attended the festival and as music lovers ourselves were solving problems we knew we and other attendees would face.

The team created rough wireframe sketches separately, then came together as a group to share ideas and evaluate. The stickies were us organizing our thoughts on common elements we were seeing across everyone's ideas.

One tricky aspect about this project was that it was to be a completely separate entity from the official SXSW website, and this meant that utilizing schedule info was a non-starter. Early concepts had ideas around a mobile experience that would highlight bands in real-time based on a person’s location.” You’re at the Fader Fort seeing Danny Brown. Earl Sweatshirt will be playing 2 blocks away in 30 minutes, here’s what MXDWN has to say about him.” If the goal of the blogger’s guide was to expose bands, this would be a great way to do it.

Another initial idea included the ability for users to make and share playlists of their favorite artists in the guide. But for business reasons, we shelved the idea for another time. We also had loftier ideas for names (I was lobbying for Under the Radar) but due to the naming system for SXSW’s tightly managed brand, were forced to keep it simple and straightforward. The final structure of the site was fairly simple.

Unfortunately I don’t have any metrics on how the site was used, how much traffic it got, or whether it led to more business for Foxtrot who was doing the site at a discount in return for a credit on the site. But it’s a project I learned a lot from, and am happy with the results. Credit for the final UI goes to Greg Anthony Thomas and Oscar Morris.

Dimensional Fund Advisors is an investment firm based in Austin that stands apart from the usual Wall Street suspects. Founded on academic research rather than market predictions, DFA takes a refreshingly different approach to managing money. While most investment firms are busy trying to time the market or pick winning stocks, Dimensional focuses on capturing returns through scientifically-tested factors that drive performance over time.

This project was similar to the Austin Film Society site redesign, but on a smaller website and with fewer stakeholders. The client being an investment firm instead of a non-profit film collective led to differences in the tone of both the design and the level of rigor that went into the design and specs, plus the content was a lot more dense.

I was involved in early UI concepting, UX design, and production on the deliverables as well as some interfacing with the offshore developers on the project. There were about 10 different templates comprising 16 different content components.

Pages were structured using a series of reusable building blocks so that the client could mix and match to make new pages as necessary, even after our contract with them ended. We created low fidelity wireframes to illustrate which blocks would be used where. Each component had its own documentation to show how it operated. This is the page for the primary nav bar.
These are some of the wireframe annotations detailing the different components within the pages, our taxonomy for them, and how they should function.
During the UI concepting phase, this was a homepage scrollytelling style animation I had been toying around with.

One of the biggest things I learned from this project was the importance of working closely with a dev team who understands my process and who can come to me with questions and problems as they arise. Despite our best efforts to detail everything as much as possible, there would still be misunderstandings that would come up, or unforeseen idiosyncrasies of frontend development we hadn’t accounted for. We were all happy with the end result, but I think we could have gotten there faster and with fewer headaches if we’d all been on the same team.

Nearly 10 years ago when I worked at Foxtrot, I was beyond excited that I got to be the lead UX designer on the revamped Austin Film Society website. The old site was pretty confusing and difficult to navigate, and because AFS does so many different things which are managed by so many different stakeholders, my role was mainly to work with these stakeholders to untangle the information architecture and ensure the most prominent areas of their site matched the prominence of the organization’s goals.

The people at the organization were terrific to work with, as was Oscar Morris who collaborated with me on the UI and did their terrific branding. The branding and site launch coincided with AFS opening AFS Cinema. While I have no quant or qual data on the success of the site, they’re still using the same design (as of March 2025), and AFS Cinema remains Austin’s only nonprofit art house theater.

The first big piece of the puzzle was a content audit, which involved mapping out the existing site and logging every “chunk” of UI and content on every page. Everything was logged into a spreadsheet, and meetings were held with the appropriate stakeholders to figure out what needed to stay and what could go, as well as who was responsible for keeping which piece updated. This was my first time doing a real content audit and working on an information architecture of this size, so I learned a lot, and when doing a project like this, I still use similar methods today.

Dev resources were limited, so bearing that in mind and wanting to maintain consistency across the site we came up with several reusable content modules. As I was going through the audit, I identified similarities where pieces of content could use the same module. This also helped us define how many times any given module was being used.

A sitemap was put together with a hierarchy that made more sense, and the content modules were color-coded and organized so we could try to highlight similarities between pages. We realized the majority of pages were pretty basic content and could be handled by a few common page templates.
For the remaining pages, we identified some common user goals and how they’d be accomplished coming from different sources.

By this point we were getting into wireframe territory to identify exactly how on the more complex pages users would accomplish their goals such as buying tickets to see a movie, donating, or signing up for classes. This was where mine and Oscar’s work began to overlap the most and where the site finally started to take shape.

The last detail I’ll leave you with is that the sitemap was originally manually created using Adobe Illustrator, which at the time didn’t have any kind of automatic layout capabilities. The manual nature of making small changes became pretty tedious, so I coded a tool to do it in a web browser. I’ve reused this tool over the years and often daydream of making a web content planning tool to simplify a lot of what I did on this project, because it’s very much a collaborative process that could benefit from having a robust, dedicated tool.
Websites and apps pay the bills, but I really like making all kinds of things.
